articles.description: Up all night, House Republicans voted pre-dawn to advance President Donald Trump’s tax and spending cuts package. The House is now starting a round of debates ahead of a final vote expected later Thursday morning. GOP leaders worked almost around the clock trying to persuade skeptical holdouts. Trump worked the phones as Republicans race to send the bill to his desk by the Fourth of July deadline. Speaker Mike Johnson had recalled lawmakers to Washington, eager to seize on the momentum of the 887-page bill's passage the day before in the Senate. Some GOP lawmakers are criticizing the legislation as straying from the party's fiscal goals. Johnson expects votes later Thursday morning.
articles.title: House GOP clears key hurdle on Trump's big bill, pushing it closer to vote

articles.description: There’s no filibuster in the House, but Democratic leader Hakeem Jeffries essentially conducted one anyway. Jeffries held the House floor for more than eight hours on Thursday, taking his “sweet time” with a marathon floor speech that delayed passage of Republicans’ massive tax and spending cuts legislation. The marathon speech gave his party a lengthy spotlight to excoriate what he called an “immoral” bill from Republicans. The speech pushed a final vote on the tax bill, initially expected in the early morning, into the daylight hours. Republicans who were sitting on the floor when Jeffries started trickled out, leaving half the chamber empty.
articles.title: Hakeem Jeffries held the House floor for hours to delay Trump's tax bill

articles.description: Airstrikes and shootings in Gaza have killed 94 Palestinians overnight, according to Gaza’s Health Ministry on Thursday. Among the dead, 45 were attempting to get humanitarian aid. Dozens of people were killed in airstrikes that pounded tents and a school sheltering displaced people in the Strip Wednesday night and Thursday morning. The ministry states over 57,000 Palestinians have died since the war began on October 7, 2023, with more than half being women and children. The deaths come as Israel and Hamas inch closer to a possible ceasefire that would end the 21-month war.
articles.title: 82 Palestinians killed in Gaza, including 38 waiting for aid, authorities say

articles.description: The steady slowdown in U.S. hiring likely continued in June as President Donald Trump’s trade wars, federal hiring freeze and immigration crackdown weighed on the American job market. When the Labor Department on Thursday releases job numbers for last month, they’re expected to show that businesses, government agencies and nonprofits added 115,000 jobs in June, down from 139,000 in May. The unemployment rate is expected to have ticked up to 4.3%, which would be the highest since October 2021. The U.S. job market has cooled considerably from the red-hot days of 2021-2023. So far this year employers have added an average 124,000 jobs a month, down from 168,000 in 2024 and a 2021-2023 average of 400,000.
articles.title: Closely watched US jobs report likely to show hiring slowed in June

articles.description: The Supreme Court has agreed to review a case on transgender students' participation in school sports. The justices said Thursday they will review lower court-rulings in favor of transgender athletes in Idaho and West Virginia. The case highlights a broader national debate over transgender rights, with more than two dozen states enacting laws restricting transgender women and girls from participating in certain sports. Some of these laws have been blocked in court. The issue has become a focal point in legislative and legal battles over the inclusion of transgender individuals in public life.
articles.title: Supreme Court will hear case about transgender students and sports teams

articles.description: Liverpool player Diogo Jota and his brother have died in a car accident in Spain, police said Thursday. The Spanish civil guard confirmed to The Associated Press that Jota and his brother were found dead after their car went off a road near the western city of Zamora. Police were investigating the causes. They said there were no other vehicles involved. The 28-year-old Jota and his brother, 25-year-old Andre Silva, both Portuguese players, were in the car. Jota also played for Portugal’s national team. Silva played with Portuguese club Penafiel in the lower divisions.
articles.title: Liverpool player Diogo Jota and his brother die in car accident

articles.description: First lady Melania Trump visited sick patients at Children’s National hospital in Washington as the children made Fourth of July arts and crafts ahead of the holiday. Trump, continuing a tradition of support by first ladies for the pediatric care center, also stopped by the hospital's rooftop "healing” garden, which she dedicated during the first Trump administration to first ladies of the United States. Trump helped the children decorate the garden for the holiday. She and chief White House groundskeeper Dale Haney inspected a new yellow rose bush donated by the White House and planted earlier in the week at the hospital garden.
articles.title: Melania Trump visits garden at Washington children's hospital

articles.description: A startup called Gigablue claims to have reached a milestone by selling 200,000 carbon credits for its ocean-based carbon capture technology. The company says its patented particles grow algae that trap carbon dioxide, which then sinks to the ocean floor. Outside scientists, however, question the effectiveness and environmental impact of this method, citing a lack of public data and concerns about marine ecosystems. Gigablue has conducted trials in New Zealand and plans to expand operations. While some buyers trust the company’s promises, experts remain skeptical about its unproven technology and the broader implications of such ocean-based carbon removal efforts.
articles.title: Scientists raise questions about startup's plan to save the ocean

articles.description: Finnish public broadcaster Yle has reported that several people were stabbed near a shopping center in the southern city of Tempere. The report says one person was detained without giving further details. News outlets said the person arrested was a man. It was not immediately clear how many people were injured in the attack, but police say the situation no longer poses a danger to others. Victims were given first aid at the scene.
articles.title: Finnish media says several people have been stabbed in the southern city of Tempere

articles.description: A volunteer searching the archives of the American Baptist in Massachusetts has found a nearly 180-year-old document shedding light on the church's support for ending slavery. The 5-foot-long scroll is a handwritten declaration signed by 116 New England ministers saying they “disapprove and abhor the system of American slavery.” The document was signed two years after the issue of slavery prompted Baptists in the south to break away and form the Southern Baptist Convention. Church officials consider the scroll one of the most important abolitionist-era Baptist documents. It was discovered in a storage room in Groton, Massachusetts.
articles.title: Anti-slavery document signed by 116 Baptist ministers in 1847 found in Massachusetts archive
